qas.question: In what decade was digital telephony transmission made possible?
What is the minimum bit rate for compressed video and audio transmission?
What is an example of an early form of digital video and audio communication?
In what form did the first dedicated videoconferencing system appear as?
What company offered the first commercial videoconferencing system?
When did video and audio transmission come into being?

plausible_answers.text: other forms of digital video and audio communication

qas.question: In November, 1984, what else was being researched?
What other minimum bit rate is not as widely used as videoconferencing?
What started to appear as the Media space was expanding world wide?
Where did the first compressed video transmission that was sold sold come from?

context: It was only <b5_0>in <a0_0>the 1980s<b5_0/><a0_0/> that digital telephony transmission networks became possible, such as with ISDN networks, assuring a minimum bit rate (usually <a1_0>128 kilobits/s<a1_0/>) for compressed video and audio transmission. During this time, there was also research into <b6_0>other forms of digital video and audio communication<b6_0/>. Many of these technologies, such as <a2_0><b7_0>the Media space<b7_0/><a2_0/>, are not as widely used today as videoconferencing but were still an important area of research. <b8_0>The first dedicated systems<b8_0/> started to appear in the market as <a3_0>ISDN networks<a3_0/> were expanding throughout the world. One of the first commercial videoconferencing systems sold to companies came from <a4_0><b9_0>PictureTel Corp.<b9_0/><a4_0/>, which had an Initial Public Offering in November, 1984.
